title: Azzurro
text:
"Azzurro" is an Italian <a href="rock%20music">pop</a> song composed by <a href="Paolo%20Conte">Paolo Conte</a> and <a href="Vito%20Pallavicini">Vito Pallavicini</a>. Its most famous version was recorded by <a href="Adriano%20Celentano">Adriano Celentano</a> in 1968.
Background.
Conte and Pallavicini wrote "Azzurro" especially for Celentano. The song describes a lonely summer in the city. Structurally it typically reflects Conte's writing style, combining simple and catchy melodies with unusual elements, like the <a href="March%20%28music%29">military march music</a> bit in the middle. Conte would record the song himself in 1985, ten years into his own solo career as a performer. Together with "Via con me" and "Sotto le stelle del Jazz", it is now one of his most popular songs.
Lyrics.
The first line of the chorus goes: "Azzurro, il pomeriggio è troppo azzurro e lungo per me . . ." (Blue, the afternoon is too long and blue for me...)
Cover versions.
The song was covered by numerous Italian singers, like <a href="Mina%20%28Italian%20singer%29">Mina</a>, <a href="Gianni%20Morandi">Gianni Morandi</a> and <a href="Rosario%20Fiorello">Fiorello</a>. Even the <a href="Italian%20football%20national%20team">Italian football national team</a> has sung the song on one occasion. German covers were done by <a href="Peter%20Rubin%20%28singer%29">Peter Rubin</a>, <a href="Die%20Toten%20Hosen">Die Toten Hosen</a>, <a href="Peter%20Alexander%20%28Austrian%20actor%20and%20singer%29">Peter Alexander</a> and <a href="Rummelsnuff">Rummelsnuff</a>. French cover by <a href="R%C3%A9gine">Régine</a>. Spanish cover by <a href="Gabinete%20Caligari">Gabinete Caligari</a>. Czech cover by <a href="Waldemar%20Matu%C5%A1ka">Waldemar Matuška</a>, (lyrics by <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Borovec">Zdeněk Borovec</a>). In the <a href="2020%20Abu%20Dhabi%20Grand%20Prix">2020 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix</a>, German F1 driver <a href="Sebastian%20Vettel">Sebastian Vettel</a> sang a farewell song to his Ferrari team after the final race for them, which was based on the song.
Arik Einstein cover.
In Israel, it is a famous song known for its Hebrew version by <a href="Arik%20Einstein">Arik Einstein</a> "Amru Lo" (Hebrew: "They told him..."), which does not feature a translation of the original lyrics, and instead lampoons a young ne'er-do-well's inexplicable obsession with the color red and a failing <a href="soccer">soccer</a> team of the same uniform color. It was also turned as a film with the <a href="Azzurro%20%28film%29">same name</a>.
Die Toten Hosen cover.
"Azzurro" (on many releases mistitled "Azzuro") was covered by <a href="Die%20Toten%20Hosen">Die Toten Hosen</a> for the album "<a href="Auf%20dem%20Kreuzzug%20ins%20Gl%C3%BCck">Auf dem Kreuzzug ins Glück</a>" as a tribute to <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a>.
The single was released with differently coloured covers: <a href="green">green</a>, <a href="Orange%20%28colour%29">orange</a>, <a href="pink">pink</a> and <a href="yellow">yellow</a>.
Music video.
The video was directed by <a href="Hanns%20Christian%20M%C3%BCller">Hanns Christian Müller</a>.
The band drives around <a href="Italy">Italy</a> in an <a href="Opel">Opel</a>, having to push-start it every time. In the end it gets stolen right before them.
